Climate change stands as one of our biggest challenges in what concerns the emergence and sustainability of cooperation
1, 2 . Indeed, world citizens build up high expectations every time a new International Environmental Summit is settled, unfortunately with few resulting solutions implemented so far. This calls for the development of more effective incentives, agreements and binding mechanisms. The problem can be conveniently framed resorting to the mathematics of game theory, being a paradigmatic example of a Public Goods Game
3 : at stake there is a global good from which every single individual can profit, irrespectively of contributing to maintain it. Parties may free ride on the efforts of others, avoiding any effort themselves, while driving the population into the tragedy of the commons
4 . Moreover, since here cooperation aims at averting collective losses, this type of dilemmas is often referred as public bad games, in which achieving collective goals often depends on reaching a threshold number of cooperative group members
